title: Unindexing transaction / generating state snapshot loop
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.12.0
CL client & version: Lodestar v1.10.0
OS & Version: Linux, Debian, Dappnode

#### Expected behaviour
After finishing the state healing progress after a fresh resync it is expected that new blocks are imported in geth and that my stakers are attesting.  


#### Actual behaviour
After the healing process only one block was attested after which my geth node has started constantly `generating state snapshot` followed by `unindexing transactions` and only once every couple of minutes does the log show `imported new potential chain segment`.
So in a nutshell, after fresh resync only one attestation was made and then geth went into a weird state of unindexing transactions and being extremely slow at importing new blocks.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Synctonize Ethereum mainnet from scratch with Geth and Lodestar. I have tried restarting both geth and lodestar, but the behavior persists. I do see the logs saying that no consensus updates were received for a while, so maybe it's a Lodestar problem, but when geth used to be synced before my resync geth was giving different logs when there was no CL running.

#### Backtrace


I also tested my disk and I'm getting expected read/write speeds so it doesn't seem to be a disk problem.
Upon further investigation it looks like this might actually be a lodestar problem. Will try to resync Lodestar. Reopening issue if issue persists.

I resynced Lodestar and it was running as expected importing new blocks. However Geth still wasn't catching up to I restarted Geth too. After the restart Geth got into healing mode again. When healing mode finished I had one block attested and then geth went into the same mode as above. Any pointers as to what might be wrong would be highly appreciated.

I'm unsure if this is an issue, rather an annoyance. Unindexing transactions is a huge disk hog, so is state snapshot generation. If both are running, it will kind of starve everything else from disk access. One solution is that you'll just have to wait it out.

The strange thing here is that the transactions should not be unindexing, unless the beacon client sent some weird messages during sync.

If it is super slow, it might be worthwhile to keep the ancients and just do a state resync. In that case, I'd recommend upgrading to latest master branch (v1.13.0-unstable) and adding `--state.scheme=path` to the flags. It's a lot faster and lighter all around.

Yeah, I also don't understand this behavior. It never happened with syncs in the past, and now it has happened twice. First time it happened I just decided to let it run and see if it would help, but after 5 days I gave up and resynced again since I figured something might be wrong since I just removed the DB and not the geth installation. The second time I deleted everything and reinstalled geth, but same thing is happening.

Consensus client is seemingly running correctly and keeping up to date, but geth is currently 8 hours behind still posting logs as above.

If you don't mind trying, can you run this command to disable unprivileged BPF code in the kernel, this will temporarily disable it until you reboot, or you can change it back manually:

```
# View current setting for 'kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled' 
# ( 0 = enabled, 1 = disabled, 2 = off but not disabled ):
sysctl kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled
```

```
# Disable unprivileged BPF / 'sysctl kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled':
sudo sysctl kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled=1
sudo sysctl net.core.bpf_jit_harden=2
sudo sysctl kernel.unprivileged_userns_clone=0
```

Then attempt to sync again as normal and see if you are able to go smoothly past that problematic block.  If you try it please do let me know if that resolves the issue for you or not.
